title: President Truman speaking to joint session of Congress
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman calls for action on high prices and housing.  Truman told a truculent Congress today that he wants immediate action on high prices and the housing shortage.  Before a joint session of Congress, which gave him scant applause and amid threats of a speedy adjournment, the President delivered in person a tough, 24 minute message to the Congress he has termed "one of the worst" in the Nation's history.  This general view shows the President at microphones of the speakers rostrum in the House.  In back of the President are Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg (R-Michigan), President pro tempore of the Senate and Joseph W. Martin, Jr. (R-Massachusetts), Speaker of the House.  Foreign diplomats, members of the House and Senate, and the President's Cabinet occupy the seats of the floor of the House.

title: Blair House
Scopenote: The Blair House, located on Pennsylvania Avenue, adjacent to the White House, is the official guest house of the United States. Doctor Lovell was the first Surgeon General of the Army.

Scopenote: The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery, located in Virginia.  It holds the body of an unidentified United States soldier who gave his life in World War I. Scopenote: Portrait of Chaim Weizmann, first President of Israel.  Original is oversized.

Scopenote: Photograph through opening of ceiling in Main Corridor showing old bronzed ceiling covered over in 1902. This is from a series of photographs of the renovation of the White House.

Scopenote: Photograph of completed concrete foundation on southwest side of White House from Housekeeper's Office (G-15). Scopenote: Photograph of northwest corner of the second floor corridor of the White House showing crack in brick wall.  From a series of photographs of the renovation of the White House.

title: Menorah given to President Truman
Scopenote: This menorah was presented to President Harry S. Truman on his birthday on May 8, 1951. It was presented to President Truman by David Ben-Gurion and Abba Eban of Israel. The 1767 bronze menorah is from the Synagogue of Buergel, near Frankfort-on-Main, Germany. A Hanukkah type for eight candles with "shammash" (servant) in the center, crowned by the double-headed Eagle of the old German Imperial Reich. The menorah is the official emblem of the State of Israel. Its shape is said to have derived from the plant known in antiquity by the name "Moriah." The olive branches surrounding the menorah represent the Jewish people's yearning for peace.
